sec.p: We observed birds for 146 h in beech and 134 h in spruce forest. Activity depended strongly on species in each of the two habitat types: Each species and the whole community (in terms of species numbers) had twice-higher activity in beech forest as compared to spruce forest (ANOVA: activity ∼ forest type, df: 1/5026, F = 15.1, p<0.001; Figure 1a). Only Crested Tits (42.4%) had higher activity in spruce forests.

We found an effect of habitat type on food preferences. Overall activity showed a significant bias towards fat-rich food ( Figure 1b). However, relative food preference did not differ significantly in both forest types. Forest type was the most important explanatory variable for activity (ANOVA: activity ∼ forest type * food type; forest type: df: 1/5020, F = 17.6, p<0.001; food type: df: 3/5020, F = 269.1, p<0.001).
